title: Morrisons to lift worker pay above living wage
text:
Tip : Use comma (,) to separate multiple quotes. Learn more... 
Tue, Sep 29, 2015, 20:57 BST - UK Markets closed Morrisons to lift worker pay above living wage By Ashley Armstrong | Telegraph – 46 minutes ago UBGXF 0.00 
Britain's fourth largest supermarket is investing £40m to raise the basic rate of pay to £8.20 an hour but is cutting extra pay for Sunday shifts 
Morrisons is increasing pay for 90,000 shop floor staff to £8.20 an hour but is axing additional pay for Sunday work. 
The supermarket chain, which is undergoing a significant overhaul under new management, said that it will invest more than £40m to increase wages for all staff from a basic rate of £6.83 an hour. 
“We have been listening to our colleagues who told us they want their pay to be more competitive and simpler," said chief executive David Potts. “By paying a significantly higher hourly rate, we are recognising the contribution of our excellent staff, who are so important to the revival of Morrisons.” 
However, Britain’s fourth biggest supermarket said that the pay hike would also be funded by making savings in other areas, such as cutting perks offered to its skilled staff, which includes butchers and fishmongers. The grocer does not pay staff for lunch breaks. 
Morrisons previously paid staff time-and-a-half for their Sunday hours. However, those who relied on the extra income from weekend shifts will be supplemented to ensure that all staff are 2pc better off next year, a spokesman clarified. 
The move by the grocer has been supported by the shop workers’ union Usdaw. 
Morrisons follows Sainsbury’s, which increased pay for 137,000 staff by 4pc to a basic rate of £7.36 an hour. Sainsbury’s also said it pays 30-minute lunch breaks for staff on eight-hour shifts. 
Tesco (Xetra: 852647 - news ) , meanwhile, pays £7.39 an hour for established workers and additional benefits, while starter wages begin at £7.02. 
A Tesco spokesman said that the supermarket was in negotiations with unions about the level of increase for starter employees to comply with the living wage legislation next year. The supermarket chain said that it will also be handing out a bonus to all staff worth 5pc of pay if Tesco hits internal turnaround targets. 
Meanwhile, Asda currently pays £6.89 an hour and will increase this to £7 next month, although it also has a bonus scheme and paid breaks. 
German discounter Lidl was the first supermarket to pay the living wage and has said it will pay its 9,000 staff at least £8.20 an hour, although it does not pay for breaks (Other OTC: UBGXF - news ) .
